Quasipotential approximation

The general form of the BSE for the scattering amplitude is in a from

M(k1′k2′,k1k2;P)=V(k1′k2′,k1k2;P)+∫d4k2′′(2π)4V(k1′k2′,k1′′k2′′;P)G(k1′′k2′′;P)M(k1′′k2′′,k1k2;P),\begin{align} {\cal M}(k'_1k'_2,k_1k_2;P)&={\cal V}(k'_1k'_2,k_1k_2;P)+\int\frac{d^4 k''_2}{(2\pi)^4} {\cal V}(k'_1k'_2,k''_1k''_2;P)G(k''_1k''_2;P){\cal M}(k''_1k''_2,k_1k_2;P),\quad \end{align} M(k1′​k2′​,k1​k2​;P)​=V(k1′​k2′​,k1​k2​;P)+∫(2π)4d4k2′′​​V(k1′​k2′​,k1′′​k2′′​;P)G(k1′′​k2′′​;P)M(k1′′​k2′′​,k1​k2​;P),​​

where V{\cal V}V is the potential kernel and GGG is the propagators for two constituent particles. Here the momentum of the system P=k1+k2=k1′+k2′=k1′′+k2′′P=k_1+k_2=k'_1+k'_2=k''_1+k''_2P=k1​+k2​=k1′​+k2′​=k1′′​+k2′′​. It can be abbreviated as

M=V+VGM.\begin{align} {\cal M}&={\cal V}+{\cal V}{G}{\cal M}. \end{align} M​=V+VGM.​​

The Gross form of proposed quasipotential propagators for particles 1 and 2 with mass m1m_1m1​ and m2m_2m2​ written down in the center of mass frame where P=(W,0)P=(W,{\bm 0})P=(W,0) with particle 2 being on shell are

g=2πiδ+(k22−m22)k12−m12=2πiδ(k20−E2)2E2[(W−E2)2−E12],\begin{align} g=2\pi i\frac{\delta^+(k_2^2-m_2^2)}{k_1^2-m_1^2}=2\pi i\frac{\delta(k^0_2-E_2)}{2E_2[(W-E_2)^2-E_1^2]}, \end{align} g=2πik12​−m12​δ+(k22​−m22​)​=2πi2E2​[(W−E2​)2−E12​]δ(k20​−E2​)​,​​

where k1=(k10,k)=(E1,k)k_1=(k_1^0,\bm k)=(E_1,\bm k)k1​=(k10​,k)=(E1​,k), k2=(k20,−k)=(W−E1,−k)k_2=(k_2^0,-\bm k)=(W-E_1,-\bm k)k2​=(k20​,−k)=(W−E1​,−k) with E1=m12+∣k∣2E_1=\sqrt{m_1^2+|\bm k|^2}E1​=m12​+∣k∣2​.

With the define of G0=g/(2πi)G_0=g/(2\pi i)G0​=g/(2πi), the four-dimensional BSE can be reduced to a three-dimensional equation in center of mass frame

iM(k′,k)=iV(k′,k)+∫dk′′(2π)3iV(k′,k′′)G0(k′′)iM(k′′,k),\begin{align} i{\cal M}({\bm k}',{\bm k})&=i{\cal V}({\bm k}',{\bm k})+\int\frac{d {\bm k}''}{(2\pi)^3} i{\cal V}({\bm k}',{\bm k}'')G_0({\bm k}'')i{\cal M}({\bm k}'',{\bm k}),\quad \end{align} iM(k′,k)​=iV(k′,k)+∫(2π)3dk′′​iV(k′,k′′)G0​(k′′)iM(k′′,k),​​

Note: the iMi{\cal M}iM and iVi{\cal V}iV are usually real. In the center of mass frame. We choose k2=k{\bm k}_2={\bm k}k2​=k and k1=−k{\bm k}_1=-{\bm k}k1​=−k.

Partial-wave expansion

To reduce the equation to one-dimensional equation, we apply the partial wave expansion,

Vλ′λ(k′,k)=∑JλR2J+14πDλR,λ′J∗(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)Vλ′λ,λRJ(k′,k)DλR,λJ(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)→Vλ′λ,λRJ(k′,k)=2J+14π∫dΩ′dΩDλR,λ′J∗(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)Vλ′λ(k′,k)DλR,λJ(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)→Vλ′λJ(k′,k)=2π∫dcos⁡θk,k′dλ,λ′J(θk′,k)Vλ′λ(k′,k)\begin{align} &{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\bm k}',{\bm k})= \sum _{J\lambda_R}{\frac{2J+1}{4\pi}}D^{J*}_{\lambda_R,\lambda'}(\phi',\theta',-\phi'){\cal V}^J_{\lambda'\lambda,\lambda_R}({\rm k}',{\rm k})D^{J}_{\lambda_R,\lambda}(\phi,\theta,-\phi) \nonumber\\ &\to{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda,\lambda_R}^J({\rm k}',{\rm k})= {\frac{2J+1}{4\pi}}\int d\Omega' d\Omega D^{J*}_{\lambda_R,\lambda'}(\phi',\theta',-\phi'){\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\bm k}',{\bm k})D^{J}_{\lambda_R,\lambda}(\phi,\theta,-\phi) \nonumber\\&\to{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}^J({\rm k}',{\rm k})=2\pi\int d\cos\theta_{k,k'} d^{J}_{\lambda,\lambda'}(\theta_{k',k}) {\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\bm k}',{\bm k}) \end{align} ​Vλ′λ​(k′,k)=JλR​∑​4π2J+1​DλR​,λ′J∗​(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)Vλ′λ,λR​J​(k′,k)DλR​,λJ​(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)→Vλ′λ,λR​J​(k′,k)=4π2J+1​∫dΩ′dΩDλR​,λ′J∗​(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)Vλ′λ​(k′,k)DλR​,λJ​(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)→Vλ′λJ​(k′,k)=2π∫dcosθk,k′​dλ,λ′J​(θk′,k​)Vλ′λ​(k′,k)​​

where the momenta are chosen as k2=(E2,0,0,k)k_2=(E_2,0,0,{\rm k})k2​=(E2​,0,0,k), k1=(W−E2,0,0,−k)k_1=(W-E_2,0,0,-{\rm k})k1​=(W−E2​,0,0,−k) and k2′=(E2′,k′sin⁡θk,k′,0,k′cos⁡θk,k′)k'_2=(E'_2,{\rm k}'\sin\theta_{k,k'},0,{\rm k}'\cos\theta_{k,k'})k2′​=(E2′​,k′sinθk,k′​,0,k′cosθk,k′​), k=(W−E2,−k′sin⁡θk,k′,0,−k′cos⁡θk,k′)k=(W-E_2,-{\rm k}'\sin\theta_{k,k'},0,-{\rm k}'\cos\theta_{k,k'})k=(W−E2​,−k′sinθk,k′​,0,−k′cosθk,k′​) with k=∣k∣{\rm k}=|{\bm k}|k=∣k∣ and k′=∣k′∣{\rm k}'=|{\bm k}'|k′=∣k′∣. NOTE: Which particle is chosen to parallel to zzz axis is related to the order of λ\lambdaλ and λ′\lambda'λ′ in dλ′λJ(θk,k′)d^{J}_{\lambda'\lambda}(\theta_{k,k'})dλ′λJ​(θk,k′​), so it can not be chosen arbitrarily. And the definition of helicity is also dependent of the definition of k1,2{\bm k}_{1,2}k1,2​. Here, λ=λ2−λ1\lambda=\lambda_2-\lambda_1λ=λ2​−λ1​ and λ1=−s1\lambda_1=-s_1λ1​=−s1​, λ2=s2\lambda_2=s_2λ2​=s2​. The scattering amplitudes M{\cal M}M has analogous relations.

Now we have the partial wave BS equation,

iMλ′,λJ(k′,k)=2J+14π∫dΩ′dΩDλR,λ′J∗(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)DλR,λJ(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)⋅[iVλ′λ(k′,k)+∫dk′′(2π)3iVλ′λ′′(k′,k′′)G0(k′′)iMλ′′λ(k′′,k)]=iVλ′λJ(k′,k)+∫k′′2dk′′(2π)3iVλ′λ′′J(k′,k′′)G0(k′′)iMλ′′λJ(k′′,k)\begin{align} i{\cal M}^J_{\lambda',\lambda}({\rm k}',{\rm k})&= {\frac{2J+1}{4\pi}}\int d\Omega' d\Omega D^{J*}_{\lambda_R,\lambda'}(\phi',\theta',-\phi')D^{J}_{\lambda_R,\lambda}(\phi,\theta,-\phi)\nonumber\\ &\cdot\left[i{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\bm k}',{\bm k})+\int\frac{d{\bm k}''}{(2\pi)^3}i{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda''}({\bm k}',{\bm k}'') G_0({\bm k}'')i{\cal M}_{\lambda''\lambda}({\bm k}'',{\bm k})\right]\nonumber\\ &=i{\cal V}^J_{\lambda'\lambda}({\rm k}',{\rm k})+\int\frac{{\rm k}''^2d{\rm k}''}{(2\pi)^3}i{\cal V}^J_{\lambda'\lambda''}({\rm k}',{\rm k}'') G_0({\bm k}'')i{\cal M}^J_{\lambda''\lambda}({\rm k}'',{\rm k}) \end{align} iMλ′,λJ​(k′,k)​=4π2J+1​∫dΩ′dΩDλR​,λ′J∗​(ϕ′,θ′,−ϕ′)DλR​,λJ​(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)⋅[iVλ′λ​(k′,k)+∫(2π)3dk′′​iVλ′λ′′​(k′,k′′)G0​(k′′)iMλ′′λ​(k′′,k)]=iVλ′λJ​(k′,k)+∫(2π)3k′′2dk′′​iVλ′λ′′J​(k′,k′′)G0​(k′′)iMλ′′λJ​(k′′,k)​​

where ∫dΩDλ1,λ2J∗(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)Dλ1′,λ2′J′∗(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)=4π2J+1\int d\Omega D^{J*}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2}(\phi,\theta,-\phi)D^{J'*}_{\lambda'_1,\lambda'_2}(\phi,\theta,-\phi)={\frac{4\pi}{2J+1}}∫dΩDλ1​,λ2​J∗​(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)Dλ1′​,λ2′​J′∗​(ϕ,θ,−ϕ)=2J+14π​ is used.

Fixed parity

For a helicity state ∣J,λ⟩=∣J,λ1λ2⟩|J,\lambda\rangle=|J,\lambda_1\lambda_2\rangle∣J,λ⟩=∣J,λ1​λ2​⟩ fulfill the party property,

P∣J,λ⟩=P∣J,λ1λ2⟩=η1η2(−1)J−s1−s2∣J,−λ1−λ2⟩≡η~∣J−λ⟩\begin{align} P|J,\lambda\rangle=P|J,\lambda_1\lambda_2\rangle =\eta_1\eta_2(-1)^{J-s_1-s_2}|J,-\lambda_1-\lambda_2\rangle \equiv\tilde{\eta}|J-\lambda\rangle \end{align} P∣J,λ⟩=P∣J,λ1​λ2​⟩=η1​η2​(−1)J−s1​−s2​∣J,−λ1​−λ2​⟩≡η~​∣J−λ⟩​​

The construction of normalized states with parity ±\pm± is now straightforward:

∣J,λ;±⟩=12(∣J,+λ⟩±η~∣J,−λ⟩⇒P∣J,λ;±⟩=12(η~∣J,−λ⟩±∣J,+λ⟩)=±12(±η~∣J,−λ⟩+∣J,λ⟩)=±∣J,λ;±⟩\begin{align} |J,\lambda;\pm\rangle&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|J,+\lambda\rangle\pm\tilde{\eta} |J,-\lambda\rangle\nonumber\\ \Rightarrow P|J,\lambda;\pm\rangle&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\tilde{\eta}|J,-\lambda\rangle\pm|J,+\lambda\rangle) =\pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\pm\tilde{\eta}|J,-\lambda\rangle+|J,\lambda\rangle) =\pm|J,\lambda;\pm\rangle \end{align} ∣J,λ;±⟩⇒P∣J,λ;±⟩​=2​1​(∣J,+λ⟩±η~​∣J,−λ⟩=2​1​(η~​∣J,−λ⟩±∣J,+λ⟩)=±2​1​(±η~​∣J,−λ⟩+∣J,λ⟩)=±∣J,λ;±⟩​​

Mλ′λJ±=⟨J,λ′;±∣M∣J,λ;±⟩=Mλ′λJ±η~Mλ′−λJ,Mλ′−λJ±=±η~Mλ′λJ±≡ηMλ′λJ±,  M−λ′λJ±=±η~′Mλ′λJ±≡η′Mλ′λJ±\begin{align} {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'\lambda}=\langle J,\lambda';\pm|{\cal M}|J,\lambda;\pm\rangle ={\cal M}^{J}_{\lambda'\lambda}\pm \tilde{\eta} {\cal M}^J_{\lambda'-\lambda},\quad {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'-\lambda}=\pm\tilde{\eta} {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'\lambda}\equiv\eta {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'\lambda},\ \ {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{-\lambda'\lambda}=\pm\tilde{\eta}' {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'\lambda}\equiv\eta' {\cal M}^{J\pm}_{\lambda'\lambda} \end{align} Mλ′λJ±​=⟨J,λ′;±∣M∣J,λ;±⟩=Mλ′λJ​±η~​Mλ′−λJ​,Mλ′−λJ±​=±η~​Mλ′λJ±​≡ηMλ′λJ±​,  M−λ′λJ±​=±η~​′Mλ′λJ±​≡η′Mλ′λJ±​​​

with η=PP1P2(−1)J1+J2−J=P(−1)1/2+J\eta=PP_1P_2(-1)^{J_1+J_2-J}=P(-1)^{1/2+J}η=PP1​P2​(−1)J1​+J2​−J=P(−1)1/2+J. The potential Vλ′λJP{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda'\lambda}Vλ′λJP​ has analogous relations.

iMλλ′=iVλλ′+∑λ′′iVλλ′′GiMλ′′λ′,η′iMλ−λ′=η′iVλ−λ′+∑λ′′iVλλ′′Gη′iMλ′′−λ′⇒iMλλ′JP=iVλλ′JP+∑λ′′iVλλ′′GiMλ′′λ′JP,iMλλ′JP=iVλλ′JP+∑λ′′iVλ−λ′′GiM−λ′′λ′JP=iVλλ′JP+∑λ′′iVλ−λ′′Gη′′iM−λ′′λ′JP⇒iMλλ′JP=iVλλ′JP+12∑λ′′iVλλ′′JPGiMλ′′λ′JP,\begin{align} & i{\cal M}_{\lambda\lambda'}=i{\cal V}_{\lambda\lambda'}+\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}_{\lambda\lambda''}Gi{\cal M}_{\lambda''\lambda'},\quad \eta'i{\cal M}_{\lambda-\lambda'}=\eta'i{\cal V}_{\lambda-\lambda'}+\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}_{\lambda\lambda''}G\eta'i{\cal M}_{\lambda''-\lambda'}\nonumber\\ &\Rightarrow i{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}=i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}+\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}_{\lambda\lambda''}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda''\lambda'},\quad i{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}=i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}+\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}_{\lambda-\lambda''}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{-\lambda''\lambda'} =iV^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}+\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}_{\lambda-\lambda''}G\eta''i{\cal M}^{J^P}_{-\lambda''\lambda'}\nonumber\\ &\Rightarrow i{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}=i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda'}+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda\lambda''}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda''\lambda'}, \end{align} ​iMλλ′​=iVλλ′​+λ′′∑​iVλλ′′​GiMλ′′λ′​,η′iMλ−λ′​=η′iVλ−λ′​+λ′′∑​iVλλ′′​Gη′iMλ′′−λ′​⇒iMλλ′JP​=iVλλ′JP​+λ′′∑​iVλλ′′​GiMλ′′λ′JP​,iMλλ′JP​=iVλλ′JP​+λ′′∑​iVλ−λ′′​GiM−λ′′λ′JP​=iVλλ′JP​+λ′′∑​iVλ−λ′′​Gη′′iM−λ′′λ′JP​⇒iMλλ′JP​=iVλλ′JP​+21​λ′′∑​iVλλ′′JP​GiMλ′′λ′JP​,​​

As shown in Eq.~(9), the amplitudes are not independent. If we only keep the independent amplitudes, the equation for definite parity can be written as

iMijJP=iVijJP+12∑λ′′iViλ′′JPGiMλ′′jJP=iVijJP+12iVi0JPGiM0jJP+∑k≠0iVikJPGiMkjJP,⇒iM^ijJP=iV^ijJP+∑kiV^ikJPGiM^kjJP.\begin{align} &i{\cal M}^{J^P}_{ij}=i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{ij}+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{\lambda''}i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{i\lambda''}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda''j} =i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{ij}+\frac{1}{2}i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{i0}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{0j}+\sum_{k\neq0}i{\cal V}^{J^P}_{ik}Gi{\cal M}^{J^P}_{kj},\nonumber\\ \Rightarrow&i\hat{{\cal M}}^{J^P}_{ij}=i\hat{\cal V}^{J^P}_{ij}+\sum_{k}i\hat{\cal V}^{J^P}_{ik}Gi\hat{\cal M}^{J^P}_{kj}. \end{align} ⇒​iMijJP​=iVijJP​+21​λ′′∑​iViλ′′JP​GiMλ′′jJP​=iVijJP​+21​iVi0JP​GiM0jJP​+k=0∑​iVikJP​GiMkjJP​,iM^ijJP​=iV^ijJP​+k∑​iV^ikJP​GiM^kjJP​.​​

where iii, jjj, kkk are the indix for the independent amplitudes and M^=fifjM\hat{\cal M}=f_if_j {\cal M}M^=fi​fj​M with f0=12f_0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}f0​=2​1​ and fi≠0=1f_{i\neq0}=1fi=0​=1 with 000 for the amplitudes with λ1=λ2=0\lambda_1=\lambda_2=0λ1​=λ2​=0.

The Bethe-Saltpeter equation for partial-wave amplitude with fixed spin-parity JPJ^PJP reads ,

iM^λ′λJP(p′,p)=iV^λ′,λJP(p′,p)+∑λ′′∫p′′2dp′′(2π)3 iV^λ′λ′′JP(p′,p′′)G0(p′′)iM^λ′′λJP(p′′,p).\begin{align} i\hat{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\rm p}',{\rm p}) &=i\hat{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda',\lambda}({\rm p}',{\rm p})+\sum_{\lambda''}\int\frac{{\rm p}''^2d{\rm p}''}{(2\pi)^3}~ i\hat{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda'\lambda''}({\rm p}',{\rm p}'') G_0({\rm p}'')i\hat{\cal M}^{J^P}_{\lambda''\lambda}({\rm p}'',{\rm p}). \end{align} iM^λ′λJP​(p′,p)​=iV^λ′,λJP​(p′,p)+λ′′∑​∫(2π)3p′′2dp′′​ iV^λ′λ′′JP​(p′,p′′)G0​(p′′)iM^λ′′λJP​(p′′,p).​​

Note that the sum extends only over nonnegative helicity λ′′\lambda''λ′′. The partial wave potential is defined as

iV^λ′λ′′JP(p′,p′′)=fifjiVλ′λJP(p′,p)=fifj2π∫dcos⁡θ [dλλ′J(θ)iVλ′λ(p′,p)+ηd−λλ′J(θ)iVλ′−λ(p′,p)],\begin{align} i\hat{\cal V}^{J^P}_{\lambda'\lambda''}({\rm p}',{\rm p}'')=f_if_j i{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}^{J^P}({\rm p}',{\rm p}) &=f_if_j 2\pi\int d\cos\theta ~[d^{J}_{\lambda\lambda'}(\theta) i{\cal V}_{\lambda'\lambda}({\bm p}',{\bm p}) +\eta d^{J}_{-\lambda\lambda'}(\theta) i{\cal V}_{\lambda'-\lambda}({\bm p}',{\bm p})], \end{align} iV^λ′λ′′JP​(p′,p′′)=fi​fj​iVλ′λJP​(p′,p)​=fi​fj​2π∫dcosθ [dλλ′J​(θ)iVλ′λ​(p′,p)+ηd−λλ′J​(θ)iVλ′−λ​(p′,p)],​​

Transformation to a matrix equation

Now We have a integral equation with singularity in G0=12E((s−E)2−ω2)G_0=\frac{1}{2 E((s-E)^2-\omega^2)}G0​=2E((s−E)2−ω2)1​ at W=E1+E2W=E_1+E_2W=E1​+E2​. This singularity can be isolated as,

It suggests the unitary is satisfied if the potential iVi{\cal V}iV is real.

With the Gauss discretization, the one-dimensional equation can be transformed as a matrix equation as

The default dimension is [G]=1[G] = 1[G]=1. Recalling that a factor of 2m2m2m should be included if a constituent particle is a fermion, we have [G]=GeVnf→[V]=[M]=GeV−nf[G] = \text{GeV}^{n_f} \to [V] = [M] = \text{GeV}^{-n_f}[G]=GeVnf​→[V]=[M]=GeV−nf​, with nfn_fnf​ being the number of fermions. Therefore, under our convention where uˉu=1\bar{u}u = 1uˉu=1, the dimension of the potential must satisfy the above requirements. This criterion can be employed to verify the consistency of the Lagrangian and the derived potential.

Code

In code, we choose VJP=V^JP/4πV^{J^P}=\hat{V}^{J^P}/4\piVJP=V^JP/4π, G→4πGG\to4\pi{G}G→4πG, and MJP=M^JP/4πM^{J^P}=\hat{M}^{J^P}/4\piMJP=M^JP/4π. Hence, the qBSE becomes

MJP=VJP+VJPGMJP.\begin{align} M^{J^P}=V^{J^P}+V^{J^P}GM^{J^P}. \end{align} MJP=VJP+VJPGMJP.​​

Such convention is consistent with that in the chiral unitary approach.

Physical observable

After extend the energy in the center of mass frame WWW into complex energy plane as zzz, the pole can be found by variation of zzz to satisfy

∣1−V(z)G(z)∣=0\begin{align} |1-V(z)G(z)|=0 \end{align} ∣1−V(z)G(z)∣=0​​

with z=ER+iΓR/2z=E_R+i\Gamma_R/2z=ER​+iΓR​/2.

With the obtained amplitude MJPM^{J^P}MJP, we can also calculate the physical observable. Note that all physical observable are at real axis, we choose the onshell momentum as

Mij(z)={[(1−VG)−1]V}ij\begin{align} M_{ij}(z)=\{[(1-VG)^{-1}]V\}_{ij} \end{align} Mij​(z)={[(1−VG)−1]V}ij​​​

with iii and kkk chosen as the onshell momentum, that is, 000 dimension for GGG, and extra dimension for VVV.

Lorentz boost

Here, we consider an process Y→m1X→m1m2m3Y\to m_1X\to m_1m_2m_3Y→m1​X→m1​m2​m3​.
To study a 1→31\to31→3 decay with the qBSE, we need consider the center of mass frame (CMS) of YYY (which is also the laboratory frame in this issue) and the m1m2m_1m_2m1​m2​ where the qBSE is applied. The momenta of initial and final particles in the CMS of YYY are

P=(M,0,0,0);  p1=(E1,p1sin⁡θ1,0,p1cos⁡θ1);  p2=(E2,p2);  p3=(E3,p3)\begin{align} P=(M,0,0,0);\ \ p_1=(E_1,{\rm p}_1\sin\theta_1,0,{\rm p}_1\cos\theta_1);\ \ p_2=(E_2,{\bm p}_2);\ \ p_3=(E_3,{\bm p}_3) \end{align}P=(M,0,0,0);  p1​=(E1​,p1​sinθ1​,0,p1​cosθ1​);  p2​=(E2​,p2​);  p3​=(E3​,p3​)​​

The momenta of particles 2 and 3 can be written with p3cm{\bm p}^{cm}_3p3cm​ with Lorentz boost

Lμν(k)=1m(E(k)kxkykzkxm+kxkxE+mkxkyE+mkxkzE+mkykykxE+mm+kykyE+mkykzE+mkzkzkxE+mkzkyE+mm+kzkzE+m),\begin{align} L^{\mu\nu}({\bm k})=\frac{1}{m}\left(\begin{array}{cccc} E({\bm k})&k_x&k_y&k_z\nonumber\\ k_x&m+\frac{k_x k_x}{E+m}&\frac{k_x k_y}{E+m}&\frac{k_x k_z}{E+m}\nonumber\\ k_y&\frac{k_y k_x}{E+m}&m+\frac{k_y k_y}{E+m}&\frac{k_y k_z}{E+m}\nonumber\\ k_z&\frac{k_z k_x}{E+m}&\frac{k_z k_y}{E+m}&m+\frac{k_z k_z}{E+m}\nonumber\\ \end{array}\right), \end{align}Lμν(k)=m1​​E(k)kx​ky​kz​​kx​m+E+mkx​kx​​E+mky​kx​​E+mkz​kx​​​ky​E+mkx​ky​​m+E+mky​ky​​E+mkz​ky​​​kz​E+mkx​kz​​E+mky​kz​​m+E+mkz​kz​​​​,​

where the (E(k),k)(E({\bm k}), {\bm k})(E(k),k) are the relative momentum between the two reference frames. Without loss of the generality, we write, Ω3cm=(cos⁡θcm,0)\Omega^{cm}_3=(\cos\theta^{cm},0)Ω3cm​=(cosθcm,0).

With the Lorentz boost the momenta in the laboratory frame can be written with the momenta in the c.m.s of particles 23 as

p2=−p3cm−p1M23[p1⋅p3cmM−E1(p1)+M23+E2cm(p3cm)];p3=p3cm−p1M23[−p1⋅p3cmM−E1(p1)+M23+E3cm(p3cm)];\begin{align} {\bm p}_2&=-{\bm p}_3^{cm}-\frac{{\bm p}_1}{M_{23}}\left[\frac{{\bm p}_1\cdot {\bm p}_3^{cm}}{M-E_1({\rm p}_1)+M_{23}}+E^{cm}_2({\rm p}_3^{cm})\right];\nonumber\\ {\bm p}_3&={\bm p}_3^{cm}-\frac{{\bm p}_1}{M_{23}}\left[\frac{-{\bm p}_1\cdot {\bm p}_3^{cm}}{M-E_1({\rm p}_1)+M_{23}}+E^{cm}_3({\rm p}_3^{cm})\right]; \end{align}p2​p3​​=−p3cm​−M23​p1​​[M−E1​(p1​)+M23​p1​⋅p3cm​​+E2cm​(p3cm​)];=p3cm​−M23​p1​​[M−E1​(p1​)+M23​−p1​⋅p3cm​​+E3cm​(p3cm​)];​​

where the p23+p1=Pp_{23}+p_1=Pp23​+p1​=P is applied, and M23=(p2+p3)2=(p2cm+p3cm)2M_{23}=\sqrt{(p_2+p_3)^2}=\sqrt{(p^{cm}_2+p^{cm}_3)^2}M23​=(p2​+p3​)2​=(p2cm​+p3cm​)2​. So, p1,2,3p_{1,2,3}p1,2,3​ can be written with (cos⁡θ1,Ω3cm,M23)(\cos\theta_1,\Omega^{cm}_3,M_{23})(cosθ1​,Ω3cm​,M23​).

The momenta in CMS of 232323 can also be written with the momentum in laboratory frame as

Pcm=P+p1M23[p1⋅PM−E1(p1)+M23+P0]=MM23p1;Pcm0=1M23[(M−E1(p1))P0+p1⋅P]=1M23(M−E1(p1))Mp1cm=p1+p1M23[p1⋅p1M−E1(p1)+M23+p10]=MM23p1;p1cm0=1M23[(M−E1(p1))p10+p1⋅p1]=1M23[(M−E1(p1))M−M232]\begin{align} {\bm P}^{cm}&={\bm P}+\frac{{\bm p}_1}{M_{23}}\left[\frac{{\bm p}_1\cdot {\bm P}}{M-E_1({\bm p}_1)+M_{23}}+P^0\right]=\frac{M}{M_{23}}{\bm p}_1; \nonumber\\ P^{cm0}&=\frac{1}{M_{23}}\left[(M-E_1({\bm p}_1))P^0+{\bm p}_1\cdot{\bm P}\right]=\frac{1}{M_{23}}(M-E_1({\bm p}_1))M\nonumber\\ {\bm p}^{cm}_1&={\bm p}_1+\frac{{\bm p}_1}{M_{23}}\left[\frac{{\bm p}_1\cdot {\bm p}_1}{M-E_1({\bm p}_1)+M_{23}}+p_1^0\right]=\frac{M}{M_{23}}{\bm p}_1; \nonumber\\ p_1^{cm0}&=\frac{1}{M_{23}}\left[(M-E_1({\bm p}_1))p_1^0+{\bm p}_1\cdot{\bm p}_1\right]=\frac{1}{M_{23}}\left[(M-E_1({\bm p}_1))M-M^2_{23}\right] \end{align}PcmPcm0p1cm​p1cm0​​=P+M23​p1​​[M−E1​(p1​)+M23​p1​⋅P​+P0]=M23​M​p1​;=M23​1​[(M−E1​(p1​))P0+p1​⋅P]=M23​1​(M−E1​(p1​))M=p1​+M23​p1​​[M−E1​(p1​)+M23​p1​⋅p1​​+p10​]=M23​M​p1​;=M23​1​[(M−E1​(p1​))p10​+p1​⋅p1​]=M23​1​[(M−E1​(p1​))M−M232​]​​

Phase space

The general expression of the decay width is given by

dΓ=12E∣M∣2dΦ,dΦ=(2π)4δ4(P−p1−p2−p3)d3p12E1(2π)3d3p22E2(2π)3d3p32E3(2π)3\begin{align} d\Gamma=\frac{1}{2E}|{\cal M}|^2 d\Phi, \quad d\Phi=(2\pi)^4\delta^4(P-p_1-p_2-p_3) \frac{d^3p_1}{2E_1(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p_2}{2E_2(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p_3}{2E_3(2\pi)^3} \end{align}dΓ=2E1​∣M∣2dΦ,dΦ=(2π)4δ4(P−p1​−p2​−p3​)2E1​(2π)3d3p1​​2E2​(2π)3d3p2​​2E3​(2π)3d3p3​​​​

To study the invariant mass spectrum of the particles 2 and 3, it is convenient to rewrite the Lorentz-invariant phase space dΦd\PhidΦ by taking as integration variables the direction of the momentum of particle 2 p2cm{\bm p}_2^{cm}p2cm​ in the center-of-mass (cm) frame of particles 2 and 3. Thus, we first rewrite the phase factor as

dΦ=(2π)4δ4(P−p1−p2−p3)d3p12E1(2π)3d3p22E2(2π)3d3p32E3(2π)3=(2π)4δ(E2cm+E3cm−W23)δ3(p2cm+p3cm)d3p12E1(2π)3d3p2cm2E2cm(2π)3d3p3cm2E3cm(2π)3\begin{align} d\Phi&=(2\pi)^4\delta^4(P-p_1-p_2-p_3) \frac{d^3p_1}{2E_1(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p_2}{2E_2(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p_3}{2E_3(2\pi)^3}\nonumber\\ &=(2\pi)^4\delta(E^{cm}_2+E^{cm}_3-W_{23})\delta^3({\bm p}^{cm}_2+{\bm p}^{cm}_3) \frac{d^3p_1}{2E_1(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p^{cm}_2}{2E_2^{cm}(2\pi)^3}\frac{d^3p^{cm}_3}{2E_3^{cm}(2\pi)^3} \end{align}dΦ​=(2π)4δ4(P−p1​−p2​−p3​)2E1​(2π)3d3p1​​2E2​(2π)3d3p2​​2E3​(2π)3d3p3​​=(2π)4δ(E2cm​+E3cm​−W23​)δ3(p2cm​+p3cm​)2E1​(2π)3d3p1​​2E2cm​(2π)3d3p2cm​​2E3cm​(2π)3d3p3cm​​​​

where W232=(M−E1)2−∣p1∣2W_{23}^2=(M-E_1)^2-|{\rm p}_1|^2W232​=(M−E1​)2−∣p1​∣2. Here the Lorentz invariance of the d3p2E(2π)3\frac{d^3p}{2E(2\pi)^3}2E(2π)3d3p​ and δ4(P−p1−p2−p3)\delta^4(P-p_1-p_2-p_3)δ4(P−p1​−p2​−p3​) is used.

In this work, we use the momentum of the particle 3 in the center of mass system of two rescattering particles. The momentum of the particle 3 has a relation p3cm=12M23λ(M232,m32,m22){\rm p}^{cm}_3=\frac{1}{2M_{23}}\sqrt{\lambda(M_{23}^2,m_3^2,m_2^2)}p3cm​=2M23​1​λ(M232​,m32​,m22​)​ with M23=(p2+p3)2=(p2cm+p3cm)2M_{23}=\sqrt{(p_2+p_3)^2}=\sqrt{(p^{cm}_2+p^{cm}_3)^2}M23​=(p2​+p3​)2​=(p2cm​+p3cm​)2​.

Owing to the three-momentum δ\deltaδ function, the integral over p2cm{\bm p}^{cm}_2p2cm​ can be eliminated. Next, the quantity d3p3cmd^3p^{cm}_3d3p3cm​ is converted to dM23dM_{23}dM23​ by the relation,

d3p3cm=E2cmE3cmp3cmM23dM23dΩ3cm,\begin{align} d^3p^{cm}_3=\frac{E^{cm}_2E^{cm}_3{\rm p}^{cm}_3}{M_{23}}dM_{23}d\Omega^{cm}_3, \end{align}d3p3cm​=M23​E2cm​E3cm​p3cm​​dM23​dΩ3cm​,​​

where M23M_{23}M23​(=E2cm+E3cm=E^{cm}_2+E^{cm}_3=E2cm​+E3cm​) is the invariant mass of the 232323 system. We would like to integrate over the magnitude of the neutron momentum p1p_1p1​, which is related to W23W_{23}W23​. Hence, the energy-conserving δ\deltaδ function is substituted as,

δ(M23−W23)=W23∣Mp1/E1∣δ(p˘1−p1)\begin{align} \delta(M_{23}-W_{23})=\frac{W_{23}}{|M{\rm p}_1/E_1|}\delta(\breve{\rm p}_1-{\rm p}_1) \end{align}δ(M23​−W23​)=∣Mp1​/E1​∣W23​​δ(p˘​1​−p1​)​​

where the p˘1\breve{\rm p}_1p˘​1​ satisfies M232=(M−E˘1)2−p˘12M_{23}^2=(M-\breve{E}_1)^2-\breve{\rm p}_1^2M232​=(M−E˘1​)2−p˘​12​.

Performing the integral over p1{\rm p}_1p1​, we obtain the final expression of the decay width,

dΦ=1(2π)5p˘1p3cm8MdΩ1dΩ3cmdM23=1(2π)3p˘1p3cm8Mdcos⁡θ1dcos⁡θ3cmdM23,\begin{align} d\Phi &=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^5}\frac{\breve{\rm p}_1{\rm p}^{cm}_3}{8M}d\Omega_1d\Omega^{cm}_3dM_{23} =\frac{1}{(2\pi)^3}\frac{\breve{\rm p}_1{\rm p}^{cm}_3}{8M}d\cos\theta_1d\cos\theta^{cm}_3dM_{23}, \end{align}dΦ​=(2π)51​8Mp˘​1​p3cm​​dΩ1​dΩ3cm​dM23​=(2π)31​8Mp˘​1​p3cm​​dcosθ1​dcosθ3cm​dM23​,​​

Here, independence of the ϕ1\phi_1ϕ1​ and ϕ2cm\phi^{cm}_2ϕ2cm​ on the integrand is applied.

where TJ=(TJ−+TJ+)/2{\cal T}^{J}=({\cal T}^{J^-}+{\cal T}^{J^+})/2TJ=(TJ−+TJ+)/2 and NJ=2J+14πN_J=\sqrt{\frac{2J+1}{4\pi}}NJ​=4π2J+1​​.

Decay width

The distribution can be obtained as

If the reflection effect is absent, for example, the πDD∗\pi DD^*πDD∗ final state. The results can be simplified further. The amplitude can be written as
